title: Lettera 22 advertisement by Giovanni Pintori
content:
Hi, can anyone tell me what typeface is this one used by Giovanni Pintori in this advertisement for Lettera 22? Thank you !

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [4258975890\_96d511dc05.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724101934/http:/typophile.com/files/4258975890_96d511dc05_0.jpg) | 39.8 KB |
author: CristinaLavosi

comments.content:
**[Derek Italic](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724101934/http:/www.fonts.com/font/monotype/derek/italic)** from Monotype looks close enough.  
There was also an **[AT Derek Italic](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724101934/http:/www.findmyfont.com/index.php/fonts/font-preview?fset=Adobe&ffam=ATDerek%20-%20Italic&fid=5efe48beadc6c39bb80978e2fb50da25&fsize=60&text=Olivetti%20Lettera%2022&fit=1)** from Adobe [1990] but it seems it's not available anymore.

More letters from the Lettera 22 manual in the same font

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724101934im_/http:/typophile.com/files/OlivettiLettera22detail_5263.jpg)
  
This is a pre-digital typeface based on Doric Italic, a design from Germany originally cut by John in Hambury [sic.] in 1892. During the 1960s and 1970s -- the era of the Lettera 22 typewriter -- Stephenson Blake called the font \_Doric 1 Italic\_. Amsterdam called it \_Old Gothic Bold\_. Fonderie Typographique Française called it \_Washington\_. See font information in Jaspert's \_The Encyclopedia of Typefaces [1970]\_.  
The font was released in the U.S. by American Typefounders Company in 1898. Here is the release specimen published by \_The Inland Printer\_:  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724101934im_/http:/typophile.com/files/DoricItalicATF1898SM_3714.jpg)
  
Monotype says that Derek Italic is "Thought to have developed from a display face first listed in 1890" A very inadequate explanation of the fact that Derek Italic is in fact Doric Italic.  
Don
